text: Hello Mr. 9 :P i use to play myself back in the day. Anyways, Are you aware that tkinter has a "destroy" feature built into quit quick and easy without having to write a spare function just to exit, though I believe there is a difference between the two. Destroy just closes/ends while the 'exit' built in feature will send a confirmation to ask before you exit/close. Interesting. PSA

author: @sinecurve9999
text: Using python 2.7, Tkinter throws an exception upon exiting.  NameError: global name 'exit' is not defined  The window fails to close... similar behavior with quit(). No "Kill?" dialogue to be found.  Any ideas on what is going on?  A cursory search shows that window closure by event handling is usually done outside of the frame. That is, you destroy the root instantiation of Tk instead of exiting the window 'app'. Curious...
